question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Find $f'(x)$ where

$f(x) = \frac{(x^2+3\sin^2(x))(e^{x^2})}{x^4+7}$

Do NOT simplify your answer.
sols:
Another method of solving this problem is to use the product rule. First
re-write the denominator of the given function using exponent notation

\begin{align*}
f(x) &= \frac{(x^2+3\sin^2x)(e^{x^2})}{x^4+7} \\
&= (x^2+3\sin^2x)(e^{x^2})(x^4+7)^{-1}\end{align*}

This is a product of three functions. The product rule can be
generalized from its two-function version to:

\begin{align*}\frac{d}{dx}(f\cdot g \cdot h) = \frac{df}{dx}\cdot g \cdot h + f\cdot\frac{dg}{dx}\cdot h + f\cdot g\cdot\frac{dh}{dx}\end{align*}

So taking the derivative, we obtain

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big( (x^2+3\sin^2x)(e^{x^2})(x^4+7)^{-1}\Big) \\
&= \Big(\frac{d}{dx}(x^2+3\sin^2x)\Big)(e^{x^2})(x^4+7)^{-1} \\
&\quad +(x^2+3\sin^2x)\Big(\frac{d}{dx}(e^{x^2})\Big) (x^4+7)^{-1} \\
&\quad + (x^2+3\sin^2x) (e^{x^2}) \Big(\frac{d}{dx}(x^4+7)^{-1}\Big) \\
&= \Big(2x+6\sin x\cos x\Big)(e^{x^2})(x^4+7)^{-1} \\
&\quad +(x^2+3\sin^2x)\Big(2xe^{x^2}\Big) (x^4+7)^{-1} \\
&\quad + (x^2+3\sin^2x) (e^{x^2})\Big(-4x^3(x^4+7)^{-2}\Big)\end{align*}

No further simplification is required, for this question.
